case_name: State of Bihar v. Kumar Rani Sayeeda Khatoon

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 97 and 98 of 1952 from High Court of Patna judgment dated 13th October 1950

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 97 and 98 of 1952. Appeals under Articles 132 1  and 133 1  c  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Decree dated the 13th October 1950 of the High Court of Judicature at Patna in Miscellaneous Judicial Cases Nos. 140 and 107 of 1950.

facts.text: Applications to High Court dated 5th July 1950 and 28th July 1950 under article 226 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: These are two companynected appeals arising out of a. companymon judgment of the High Court of Patna on two applications to it dated the 5th July, 1950 and 28th July, 1950, under article 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: State of Bihar is the appellant in both appeals

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bihar is the appellant in both the appeals.

facts.text: Kumar Rani was born in the territory of India

anchor.surface_text: Kumar Rani was admittedly born in the territory of India and claims to be the lawfully wedded wife of Captain Maharaj Kumar Gopal Saran Narayan Singh of Gaya

facts.text: Kumar Rani created wakf of properties consisting of 427 villages on 4th May 1946

anchor.surface_text: In 1946 she created a wakf of her properties companysisting of 427 villages for the maintenance and support of herself, her three sons and their descendants, by executing a deed of Wakf-ulalAulad dated the 4th May, 1946, by which she divested herself of all her interest in the said properties and vested them in Almighty God.

facts.text: Kumar Rani appointed herself sole mutwalli for lifetime and her three sons to succeed as joint mutwallis

anchor.surface_text: She appointed, herself as the sole mutwalli for her life time or until relinquishment, and her three sons to succeed her as joint mutwallis. The deed also provided that the net income was to be spent for the maintenance of herself and her three sons

facts.text: Kumar Rani went to Karachi in July 1948

anchor.surface_text: In July, 1948, Kumar Rani went to Karachi.

facts.text: Kumar Rani returned to India from Pakistan in December 1948 on temporary permit

anchor.surface_text: In December, 1948, she returned to India from Pakistan on a temporary permit and went back to Pakistan in April, 1949.

facts.text: Kumar Rani went back to Pakistan in April 1949

anchor.surface_text: In December, 1948, she returned to India from Pakistan on a temporary permit and went back to Pakistan in April, 1949.

facts.text: Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance 1949 came into force on 21st June 1949

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st June, 1949, the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949  Bihar Ordinance No. III of 1949  came into force.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian issued notification on 2nd September 1949 declaring wakf properties as evacuee property under section 5

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Custodian of Evacuee Property issued a numberification on the 2nd September, 1949, under section 5 of this Ordinance, declaring all the properties companyprised in the abovementioned wakf estate to have vested in the Custodian as being evacuee property.

facts.text: Custodian took possession of wakf properties between 20th September and 2nd October 1949

anchor.surface_text: He took possession thereof between the 20th September and 2nd October, 1949.

facts.text: Kumar Rani came back to India on 14th May 1950 under permanent permit

anchor.surface_text: On the 14th May, 1950, Kumar Rani again came back to India under a permanent permit obtained from the High Commissioner for India in Pakistan.

facts.text: Permanent permit cancelled on 12th July 1950 by Deputy High Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: This permit was, however, cancelled on the 12th July, 1950, by the Deputy High Cominissioner,on the ground that this was wrongly issued, without the companycurrence of the Government

facts.text: Sub-Inspector of Police Gaya issued notice to Kumar Rani to leave India by 31st July 1950, order dated 23rd July 1950

anchor.surface_text: In view of this cancellation, the Sub-Inspector of Police, Gaya, issued numberice to Kumar Rani directing her that since her permanent permit had been cancelled, she should leave lndia by the 31st July, 1950.

facts.text: High Court allowed both applications

anchor.surface_text: Both these applications were allowed by the High Court and hence these appeals by the State on leave granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Appeals heard before Supreme Court on 26th and 27th October 1953, Appeal No. 97 remanded to High Court for finding

anchor.surface_text: These two companynected appeals came up for hearing be-fore this Court on the 26th and 27th October, 1953. This Court after hearing companynsel on both sides was of the opinion that one of the essential facts [...] requisite for a proper decision of Appeal No. 97 had been assumed without investigation and that it was necessary to have a finding thereupon after taking evidence. This Court accordingly re- manded Appeal No. 97 to the High Court

facts.text: Kumar Rani went to Karachi in July 1948 temporarily for medical treatment - story doubted by High Court and Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: As regards her allegation that when she first went to Karachi in July, 1948, she did so temporarily for the purpose of medical treatment, the learned Judges of the High Court were number inclined to accept her story. [...] Her story that she went there temporarily for medical treatment has been doubted by the High Court and appears to us to be unfounded.

facts.text: In temporary permit application December 1948, Kumar Rani stated domiciled in Pakistan representing as Pakistani national

anchor.surface_text: When she came to India in December, 1948, she did so on a temporary permit stating in her application for the said permit that she was domiciled in Pakistan and accordingly representing herself to be a Pakistani national.

facts.text: Kumar Rani letter dated 2nd June 1949 relinquishing mutwalli office found not genuine by High Court on remand

anchor.surface_text: She had written a letter dated the 2nd June, 1949, addressed to her ,second son, Kumar Fateh Singh, whereby she relin- quished the office of mutwalli [...] The genuineness of this letter has been challenged [...] The 7 High Court having taken evidence on the matters at the hearing after remand and having companysidered the same, has clearly found that the letter was number genuine.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on February 10 1955

anchor.surface_text: 1955. February 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J.-

facts.text: Court finds Kumar Rani migrated to Pakistan after 1st March 1947

anchor.surface_text: There can be numberdoubt on these facts that she must be held to have migrated from the territory of India after the 1st March, 1947.

facts.text: Permanent permit invalid as issued without concurrence of Government, properly cancelled

anchor.surface_text: Rule 10 [...] provides that a permit for permanent resettlement in India may be granted by the High Commissioner or Deputy High Commissioner only after securing the agreement of the State [...] the permit has been cancelled [...] on the ground that, on the facts of the case, the companysent of the State Government companycerned should have been obtained before the permit companyld be issued. This is a case [...] number of a valid permanent permit

facts.text: Kumar Rani not a citizen of India under Article 7

anchor.surface_text: she must be held to have migrated [...] Even if therefore article 5 can be said to be applicable to her [...] the facts bring her case under article 7. Article 7 clearly overrides article 5. [...] The applicant, is, therefore, number a citizen of India

facts.text: Wakf properties vested in Custodian as evacuee property of Kumar Rani

anchor.surface_text: the original numberification vesting the wakf property in the Custodian was made under section 5 of the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949. [...] We are of the opinion that the Bihar definition companyprised also wak property and interest therein.

arguments.claim: Kumar Rani migrated after 1 March 1947 bringing case under Art 7

anchor.surface_text: There can be no doubt on these facts that she must be held to have migrated from the territory of India after the 1st March, 1947.

arguments.claim: Art 7 overrides Art 5; no exception for wife leaving husband in India

anchor.surface_text: But article 7 says Notwithstanding anything in article 5, a person who has after the first day of March, 1947, migrated ... Article 7 clearly overrides article 5.

arguments.claim: Permanent permit invalid as issued without concurrence of State Government per Rule 10; properly cancelled

anchor.surface_text: Rule 10 ... provides that a permit for permanent resettlement in India may be granted ... only after securing the agreement of the State ... the permit has been cancelled ...

arguments.claim: Kumar Rani is evacuee under Bihar Ordinance definition

anchor.surface_text: an evacuee is defined as follows in the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 A person who, on account of the setting up ... left ... on or after 1st Nov 1946

arguments.claim: Relinquishment letter dated 2 June 1949 not genuine

anchor.surface_text: The High Court ... has clearly found that the letter was not genuine. We have gone through the finding ... and can find no reason not to accept it.

arguments.claim: Evacuee property definition in Bihar Ordinance includes wakf property and mutwalli interest

anchor.surface_text: the definition of the phrase evacuee property ... Evacuee property means any property in which an evacuee has any right or interest or which is held by him under any deed of trust

arguments.court_reasoning: Words of sufficient amplitude; confirmed by repealing central laws definitions and s8(2)

arguments.claim: Successive repeals by Central Ordinance XXVII 1949 and Act XXXI 1950 continue vesting in Custodian including trustee interest

anchor.surface_text: This Ordinance was repealed by section 55(2) of Central Ordinance No. XXVII of 1949 ... each contain section 8(2) providing ... shall continue to so vest.

holdings.text: Kumar Rani must be held to have migrated from the territory of India after the 1st March, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: There can be nodoubt on these facts that she must be held to have migrated from the territory of India after the 1st March, 1947. Even if therefore article 5 can be said to be applicable to her [...]

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of travel to Pakistan in 1948 without temporary intent, self-representation as Pakistani, and delayed return attempt establish migration post-1 March 1947.

holdings.text: Article 7 overrides Article 5 and applies even to a wife migrating to Pakistan leaving her husband in India; Kumar Rani is not a citizen of India.

anchor.surface_text: But article 7 says Notwithstanding anything in article 5, a person 1264 who has after the first day of March, 1947, migrated ... Article 7 clearly overrides article 5. [...] The applicant, is, therefore, not a citizen of India

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 7 expressly overrides Art 5; peremptory language makes no exception for wives; facts bring case under Art 7.

holdings.text: Permanent permit was invalidly issued without State Government concurrence per Rule 10 and properly cancelled per Rule 29; proviso to Article 7 has no application.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 10 of the Permit System Rules, 1949, framed by the Central Government under section 4 of the Influx from Pakistan Control Act, 1949, provides that a permit for permanent resettlement in India may be granted by the High Commissioner or Deputy High Commissioner only after securing the agreement of the State [...]

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permit required State agreement under Rule 10, which was absent; cancellation valid under Rule 29; thus no valid return for resettlement under Art 7 proviso.

holdings.text: Order dated 23rd July 1950 directing Kumar Rani to leave India was valid.

anchor.surface_text: the permit has been cancelled [...] on the ground that, on the facts of the case, the consent of the State Government concerned should have been obtained before the permit could be issued. This is a case [...] not of a valid permanent permit

holdings.reasoning_summary: As non-citizen without valid permit, no fundamental right under Art 19; order lawful.

holdings.text: Kumar Rani is an evacuee under the definition in the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: an evacuee is defined as follows in the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 A person who, on account of the setting up ... left ... on or after 1st Nov 1946 [...] She has, therefore, been rightly taken to be an evacuee by the Custodian.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Migration after 1 March 1947 (post-1 Nov 1946) in circumstances of partition fits definition.

holdings.text: Letter dated 2nd June 1949 relinquishing mutwalli office was not genuine.

anchor.surface_text: She had written a letter dated the 2nd June, 1949, addressed to her ,second son, Kumar Fateh Singh, whereby she relinquished the office of mutwalli [...] The High Court having taken evidence on the matters at the hearing after remand and having considered the same, has clearly found that the letter was not genuine.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding after remand and evidence accepted by Supreme Court as no reason to reject.

holdings.text: Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 applies to wakf property and mutwalli's beneficial interest therein; vesting in Custodian valid and continued post-repeals.

anchor.surface_text: the definition of the phrase evacuee property in the Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949, [...] Evacuee property means any property in which an evacuee has any right or interest or which is held by him under any deed of trust [...] We are of the opinion that the Bihar definition comprised also wakf property and interest therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition words of sufficient amplitude include trustee interest; confirmed by repealing Central laws' broader definitions and s8(2) continuance provisions.

anchor.surface_text: This contention must, therefore, fail. This appeal also must accordingly succeed. In the result both the appeals are allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All substantive issues resolved in favor of State of Bihar.

justification_sets.label: Bihar Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance 1949 support

anchor.surface_text: In the result both the appeals are allowed. The appellant in the circumstances will get only the costs incurred before the High Court on remand in Civil Appeal No.

outcome.relief_summary: Both Civil Appeals Nos. 97 and 98 of 1952 are allowed; High Court orders in the respondents' applications under Article 226 set aside
directions: Appellant entitled only to the costs incurred before the High Court on remand in Civil Appeal No. 97
